Numbers: 173 – 198

At the beginning of this week I went into a charity shop and bought, what I believed to be, Mousie-Mousie. I thought this would make a good gift for my sister, we used to play it during the Seventies and the box was identical to the one we used to have.

It was sealed with a ridiculous amount of sellotape, but the lady assured me that it had been checked and that all of the pieces were inside. However, when I got home and opened it – not a mouse in sight. Instead, some old Monopoly parts.

I thought they were 1960s, at first, but after some research I discovered that they are nearer 1950s. Exciting, but I didn’t quite take that in until this morning, when it suddenly dawned on me that the cards I have been sewing all week are sixty years old. Turns out, the metal counters were made after the war and represent the power and rebuilding of Britain. The piece I thought was a tractor, is a bulldozer. I am going to add the counters to our family set, which is ultra-modern, each player actually uses a credit card. The children love it. From now on, though, I shall be moving this Mallard around our board.

Anyway, an unplanned week of frenzied sewing ensued. A bonus unexpected day off work, on Thursday, helped. My accounts were not completed (and many pans boiled dry), but the cards were. I have never had such a quick turnaround from acquiring the goods, to transforming them into the finished piece. Sometimes I sit on things for years before turning them into something new.

The peak of the week was when I had the idea to include a Community Chest or Chance Card, and some money, with each card. Hello!

They are not made from my usual food packaging, but instead from some WH Smith’s index cards. The index cards were bought new by a friend. She never used them and gave them to me last Sunday, rather than throw them away. So they were still in my bag when I bought Mousie-Mousie, seemed only right to use them here. The envelopes, I bought some years ago from a charity shop, I have just adapted them for purpose.

I am now going to put a few in my shop (not Northumberland Avenue, though – more on that later).

Hope you like them,

Alison

Number: 206

Ages ago, I’m thinking about five years, I made a hundred of these reindeer postcards.

Months and months I spent making them, our tiny house in Hither Green was covered in little orange shreds of card. Then I posted them, all but two, to people who I thought might be interested in my work. I had one reply by email, from a true gent in Gateshead. He wanted to let me know how much he liked it. His words were very much appreciated, and I still think of them sometimes. Anyway, so is life.

I  rediscovered little Rudolf recently, and thought to myself I might make some more, only this time using my red shirts for the noses. I called myself The Upcyclist in those days, so I’ve updated the card by adding my name and remounting it. I can’t remember anything about the map I used, but this section is the English Channel.

You can find this card in my shop.

All I need to do now, is find the last remaining card. I put it somewhere ‘safe’ so I could give it to a friend. The reindeer was standing on Margate, which is particularly fitting for this friend. If you’re reading C, you’ll get it one day.

I have not mentioned the ‘C’ word once (well, apart from my friend), but apologies anyway.

Have a great weekend,

Alison x

261

A very windy Friday, here in London.

Some of you know that I like to have a little lunch time sewing on the go, at all times. I finished this little button piece  about three weeks ago now, but just haven’t managed to write a post about it.  It has been made using the buttons from my colleagues’ shirts, mainly during my lunch breaks in the gallery. There is really good light in the kitchen, despite it being further underground than the Northern Line.

It’s funny, but when I look at all of my work there is always something I am reminded of, something that was happening at the time of its making. A conversation, something on television, something I was cooking. Below is what I will think about whenever I look at these particular buttons.

The red fabric, onto which the buttons are sewn, is my very own actual shirt, by the way. I won’t bore you with the name of the person who once wore each individual button, but I know, and they are all noted.

Have a great weekend,

Alison

Sunday 22nd September

Today, I was sitting in the kitchen at work sewing my buttons, whilst listening to the conversation going on around me.

If you don’t know, ‘VSA’ is Visitor Services Assistant, which is one of my jobs. Wandering around a gallery asking the public not to do stuff and pointing them in the direction of the loo.

VSA 1: When I lived in Brazil I had a cleaner.

Group of VSAs: Wow……You lucky thing……… wish I had a cleaner, but I would clean up before they came…., and such like.

Boss, who happened to be making himself a cup of tea: I have a cleaner, don’t know what I’d do without her. I used to get her through an agency and I paid the agency £9 an hour, she told me the agency paid her £6. So I got her to quit the agency…

Like me, you are probably thinking that my boss was about to say that he told his cleaner to stop working for the agency so that he could give her the full £9 instead. Or what the hell, make it £10. Wrong!

….. and now I pay her £6 too, and save myself £3.

Not sure which I’m more astonished about, the fact that he is so mean, or the fact that he was boasting about it.

224

Numbers: 224 – 229

Hello.

This week I have been making ‘Get Well Soon’ cards. Six in total. All different.

It sort of came about when I was making that Picasso piece, as I was using the same fabrics.

All of the bottles are made from my extremely large Eighties shirt. I never had it off my back when I was sixteen (eeek, thirty years ago), and it accompanied me to Newcastle City Hall on many, many occasions. Do you remember when you could see a band for £3.50? Anyway, I have had some good times in that shirt.

The red crosses are, of course, my uniforms.

The blue bits are my daughter’s old monsoon skirt, which came to us via a charity shop. When we lived in Hither Green she did not wear a school uniform, she would’ve worn this skirt every day. It had a huge sparkly butterfly on it.

The white squares are taken from my son’s old school shirt.

The purple lids are made from Del’s old shirt. He took me to Lewisham hospital when I was in labour.

If you are interested, there are pictures of the clothes on the Picasso post.

I wanted to find food packaging with a plainish background. So, we have, Waitrose Oatcakes, Pizza Express, Thai Supper For Two, Earl Grey Tea, and, M&S Crispy Cheese Crackers. With the possible exception of the crackers, I had not tasted any of these things when I was sixteen.

I am now going to put a couple in my shop.

Happy Birthday to my husband, try to hurry home tonight as our daughter is making you a giant cheese biscuit x

Have a great weekend,

Alison

P.S. I just looked at a preview of this post, before posting. At the bottom it said ‘Some of your visitors may see an advert here’. What?? Don’t like the sound of that. Any other WordPressers know anything about it? I will look into it. In the meantime, I apologise if you see an unwanted/unagreed-to advert.

Numbers: 207 – 216

To recap, I am clearing out my ‘stock’ whilst searching for something from 1973. I keep finding stuff and getting sidetracked.

One of the things I unearthed, was the remains of The Surprise Party by the wonderful Pat Hutchins. It was first published in 1970, but this edition is from 1972 (so close).

Pat Hutchins won a scholarship to Darlington School of Art (a few miles from my home town) in 1958. She has written and illustrated about 50 books, and given countless children lots of pleasure over the years. One of these children was me. I can remember the lovely Mrs. Yates reading this to my class when I was sixish. Mrs. Yates was a hippy, and I loved her. I was totally beguiled by the illustrations. Here was a person who had outlined her images in dark green, not black. Was that allowed? I think I can trace my colourful sewing outlines right back to Pat Hutchins, now I come to think about it.

A few years back, I made a few little cards with this book. It was before I discovered the internet and blogging, so I have no record of these. Some sold and some didn’t. When I acquired the book, it was damp and moldy. I usually accommodate scribbles and sellotape, and incorporate these into my work, but I figure nobody wants mold and I always amputate  it. The pages that I recently found did not have mold on them and were too good to cut into little squares. I remember thinking that I would put them somewhere safe and eventually use them for postcards, that way the illustrations wouldn’t need to be cut. I was so excited when I rediscovered these pages, that I stopped my ‘sorting’ and immediately started making.

The result is ten pretty large postcards, which have been made with used food packaging.

I will put a few into my shop. If the one you like isn’t there, please give me a shout.

If you prefer my folded cards, there are five left from my original make a few years ago. My intention is to remount them over the weekend, and post some pictures on Tuesday.

The images below are quite small, but I think if you click on them you will see a larger version.

Have a lovely weekend,

Alison x

Number: 243

Louise, one of my lovely customers, has asked me if I have anything from 1973, with which to make her boyfriend a card.

Using this as an excuse, I have been slowly sorting through my ‘stock’. The trouble is, I keep finding exciting things I had forgotten about, which leads  promptly to making something.

On Saturday I found myself with the house to myself, and the cover from ‘The Portobello Road’ by Muriel Spark in my hand. I love Muriel Spark, The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie is one of my favourite books, although I have never read this story.

I came about the cover from this book in a sad fashion.

About eight years ago, I was unexpectedly ill. There was a point when I though I was dying. It is not apparent to the casual observer, but I am still not over it, nowhere near over it. To cut a very long story short, my illness was due to some botched-up dental work done some fifteen years earlier. A dental job had gone wrong, this resulted in a skin graft in hospital. The skin graft was done incorrectly, sealing in an infection. An infection which secretly grew and grew, until eight years ago my body had a massive allergic reaction. Every joint was swollen and I could not move. Every month or so I went to hospital and had the joints ‘drained’, upon which they immediately refilled. I was in a wheelchair at first, and then crutches. I couldn’t even move my jaw, much to the relief of some.

The trouble was, we had no idea what was wrong with me. I had test after test. Nothing. Until two years ago I was lucky enough to see a new dentist, Mark. Mark had me to the hospital within a week. I had had every part of my body x-rayed loads of times, but nobody had thought to do my head. It was filled with ‘matter’. Problem solved. Almost.

It sounds  stupid saying this, but the hardest part was finding out who genuinely cared about me and who didn’t. My heart was broken during that period, and it is proving a lot harder to fix than my joints.

Here is just one little story.

A lot of people didn’t know I was ill until about three months into my illness, when my absence was suddenly noted. My friend T came round to see me. As it turned out she didn’t actually come to see me, as always she came to ask something of me. We have been friends since the age of sixteen. When you can’t move and you are in pain, there is pretty much nothing to do other than think.Thinking. Too much thinking can be a bad thing. I thought about all the things I had done for T over the years, not just me, the rest of this particular friendship group had done a lot for her as well. Between us, we had pretty much spoonfed this woman. I tried to think of a favour I had ever asked of her, I couldn’t think of a single one. Despite the fact that she was one of my few friends who had a car at the time, she never, ever brought me any food packaging. I thought about my friends who never visited me without making deep red marks in their hands from carrying one to many cereal boxes on the bus. Some people just take and never give. I had never noticed.

Anyway, back to the day of her visit (did I say it was my birthday, by the way? I had honestly not been bothered that I always sent her a card, and that we always went out for a drink for her birthday, yet she still didn’t know my birth date.  Suddenly, after 23 years, it mattered). She asked me how I was doing. I told her that it was very difficult and painful  to move my hands to sew, and I was really missing it. Ignoring this, she produced a load of stuff from her bag and asked me if I could make a collage for her mum’s birthday (did I mention that she had been to art college too?). And I thought my joints were painful. This pain was worse, still is worse.

One of the things she gave me was this Muriel Spark book. She had bought the book especially for the job “It was only 60p, one of the Mini Penguin Classics”, and she proceeded to tear off the cover, right before my eyes. Did she know me at all?

Of course, I spent my birthday weekend making the collage. I could not bring myself to use the book cover, though. Many tears fell on that work. I will not be making anything else for T.

So, I found the cover in my clearout and made this little postcard. Maybe, by way of a little therapy.

The cover illustration is beautiful and was done by Sarah McMenemy. This edition was printed in 1995.

I am putting it in my shop, although I can’t think who would want to buy it after that hard sell! It is lovely, though. I feel better for having made it, and looking at it now is making me smile.  I don’t know what the market is like nowadays, as I haven’t been for years, but it used to be great. And then there is that fantastic scene from ‘Notting Hill’, where Hugh Grant walks through the market and the seasons change. Is that Portobello Road or have I just fantasized it?

Alison.

Numbers: 217 – 223 and 249 – 253

Just spent about five minutes totally dumbstruck watching the news, before realising that it’s not a three hundred year old man that has been found in a box in someone’s garage, but a three hundred years old manuscript!

Back to the point. I have remounted the five old cards I found a few weeks ago, and made some new ones, with the remaining bits of unmoldy book.

221, 222 and 223 are very tiny, I will give them as gifts rather than put them in my shop.

Sorry for the briefness of this post, but I am due at work soon, and I promised that I would post this today.

If there is a particular card you fancy, and you don’t see it in my shop, please give me a shout.

Alison x

P.S. Last night I found a stash of used wrapping paper in one of my piles. Already started making some Christmas postcards with it. If you are a customer you can expect a few in the post, hopefully early in November.

Numbers: 264 – 301

I have been making cards for as long as I can remember, but only selling them for about ten years. Until I became internet-friendly, I always managed to make my customers a few christmas cards to say ‘Thank you’.

I was determined to reintroduce this tradition this year.

I had a book in mind for the job, but then I stumbled upon a stash of used wrapping paper. I’m pretty certain that the paper was originally from Paperchase, although I could be wrong.

I have used two designs, and made postcards using my usual cereal boxes. I am not going to show all the cards, they are very similar and it would be tedious.

I am experimenting with packaging, and although the lady in the post office said there would be no problem with sewn envelopes (made from old copies of Completely London), I am a little worried they won’t get to you. If you have the time, could you please let me know when they arrive? If all of the envelopes arrive safely, and in one piece, then I may continue to package my stuff in this way. Be honest, let me know if you have any problems, I would appreciate the feedback. It also bothers me that I have used new, unused tissue paper to wrap the cards. I need to come up with an alternative.

Anyway, if you have bought a card (or cards) from me this year, a few of these are on their way to you (C, I will give you yours when I see you). It has been lovely getting to know you all, thank you and I hope you like the cards.

See you on Friday,

Alison

P.S. This is the cake I talked about a few posts ago, made by my daughter.

Hello from Bromley Library.

Due to a computer malfunction, I have been absent from social media and such like this week. This is likely to continue next week. I have been using my son’s kindle for small stuff, but it drives me nuts.
I am sorry that I haven’t been able to visit your blogs, facebook pages, et cetera, but hopefully I will be back the week after next.

Things I made this week (and last), but can’t yet share:
Christmas Postcards

Alison x

Numbers 230 – 239

Happy Friday Everyone.

It’s good to be back after two weeks of computer problems. No surprise to me, though, that I manged to do loads of making without the seductions of the internet.

First up, ten little new home cards. I’m really pleased with these. Made, as usual, from used food packaging and clothes which have seen better days.

Mostly, I tend to use fabrics which happen to be in front of me, rather than hunting for stuff. So if you recognise anything here, that is because I used it to make my recent Picasso piece (it’s his birthday today, by the way, 1881). All of the houses are made from those red shirts (will I ever get to the end of the pile?), the doors and windows are made from Del’s shirt and my daughter’ skirt, the yellow roofs are Jade’s dress. You can read more about these clothes here.

Some of the roofs are made from a map, it was a page from a magazine. I have no idea about the magazine or the page. Maybe some of you might recognise it?

There are two new clothes items:

Purple gingham dress. Very special. I bought this in Scope, Lewisham, 2005. My daughter was three at the time, and was with me and a buggy-load of the usual fruit and veg we had just bought at the market. It must’ve been a Friday. It was a beautiful little shift dress that someone had hand-made for a small girl. It was perfect. There was a small red felt-tip mark at the hem, which I did not try to remove. My daughter wore it for years, first as a dress and then as a top over leggings. There are too many happy memories to mention in which this dress was present.

Green blouse with yellow floral print. My mam’s. She likes to wear synthetic clothing, which I don’t normally use in my work. However, she wore this to my sister’s graduation. It was perfect for the little hill on which every house stands.

I have made ten of these houses, each one is different. They will not be repeated, these will be the only ten. A couple can be found in my shop.

Have a great weekend,

Alison

3a Things We Like by W. Murray, illustrated by Martin Aitchison. Ladybird.

It’s about a year since I first started to interfere with social media. Those of you who have known me since the start will know that I used to be called Upcyclist. Sounds a bit pompous now. I had been making stuff under this name for quite few years before joining Twitter (my first venture into modern life), which I loved. I then joined Facebook, which I hated.

After a while, I realised that I really should use my name, it seemed like I was hiding. So I started again, using Alison Sye.

The trouble is, I have spent years making cards, which now display old website information. They are all individually numbered, I got well into the 600s before starting again at number 1 as Alison Sye. None of the Upcyclist numbers are recorded, so you won’t find any details on this blog. To be honest, I can’t remember most of the details about the books and materials I used. Actually, this was my sole reason for starting a blog. I used to try and fit as much information about the book’s history onto the back of the card. It was ridiculous, my cards are pretty small. I wanted the buyer to know all the stuff involved in the making, but it was taking ages to record, one at a time.

And so this blog began. The idea being that you look up the number of your piece, and find the story. I do feel bad, though, that I am excluding non-internet-friendly folk. Some of my best friends are non-internet-friendly folk. Niffs!

Recently I found some christmas tree cards, made from an old Ladybird book. Like I said, I didn’t think to write down too many details at the time, so I don’t know the date or how I acquired the book. Most of the stuff I used then was given to me by local schools and libraries when they were having a clear out. I had ‘inside-men’, as it were. I do know, though, that this book is at least thirty-five years old. I also know that it was beyond reading, I wouldn’t have cut it up otherwise.

Anyway, gradually I am going to sell the old cards in my shop, at a much reduced rate. I spent all of yesterday trying to take photographs, most of which were blurred. Once I have a bit of cash I am going to be asking you for camera purchasing advice.

Have a great weekend,

Alison

This Is The House Where Jack Lives by Joan Heilbroner, illustrated by Aliki. This edition was published in 1977 by The Windmill Press.

Last week I talked about the fact that I used to be called Upcyclist, and that I am going to be selling off my old cards at a reduced rate.

Well, here are said cards, although there are more in my shop.

The illustrations are by the wonderful Aliki. At the time of making these cards I had never heard of her, and had written her name on the card info’ without giving it much thought. I remember thinking it was strange the illustrator only had a single name, and shamefully thought it was a man. Aliki has since become one of my heros (I have a small collection), so I was amazed when I opened the shoe box (all of my cards are kept in shoe boxes) to discover who had done the illustrations. It wasn’t that I had forgotten the book, I remembered it vividly, I just hadn’t taken on board the name of the illustrator.

Very sorry for the short post, it is my daughter’s birthday, hence the cake at the top, which she made herself, and don’t think I don’t feel bad about it!

Have a great weekend,

Alison x

PS. I am not using my new packaging until I know that every one of those Christmas cards arrived safely, so far I have heard from about 80% of the receivers.

Look At This by W. Murray. Illustrations by J.H. Wingfield. First published in 1964 by Ladybird. Don’t know when this edition was published, but it originally cost 24p.

An extremely quick post to say that I have added some more sale cards to my shop.

Every order before 15th December 2013, will come with a complimentary Christmas postcard.

Alison x

It is a glorious, crisp November day here in South London. The birds are singing, or they were earlier on as I was walking home with the shopping.

This morning I posted a picture of my son’s creepy art homework on facebook (all ‘likes’ very welcome, by the way), and asked for guesses at the subject. His task was to find a ‘celebrity’ and cover them in sweet wrappers. That is, to find a picture of the ‘celebrity’, not actually hunt one down. This would be a criminal offence in some countries, of course.

And nobody has guessed, and it has really made me laugh hearing the fab suggestions.

So I got to thinking, that I could give away a little card selection to the first person who guesses correctly.

Please, make your suggestions below. Facebook have all kinds of rules about giveaways, it’s a minefield.

Good luck

Alison x

P.S. Not sure how well known this person is overseas, sorry.

Fun On The Farm by W. Murray. Published by Ladybird Books. Not sure of the date but it originally cost 24p. Illustrated by J.H. Wingfield.

The day before yesterday I posted a spur-of-the-moment giveaway. It was to guess which ‘celeb’ my son had covered in sweet wrappers. Unsurprisingly, nobody has guessed it yet. So here are a few clues, which may not seem like clues, but they actually are. You can take part here.

1. It is a man.

2. He is English.

3. According to Wikipedia, he is known in New Zealand and Australia (I had previously said that overseas readers may struggle).

4. My husband doesn’t like him, due to an incident which happened last year.

5. My mam and daughter have never heard of him.

6. He is not Oprah, Michael Jackson, the man from the antiques programme, Babs, Gary Lineker, Noel Edmunds, Keith Lemon, Mick-Simply-Red, Harry Styles, Simon Cowell, Noel Fielding, Cheryl Cole, Rusty Lee, Elton John or Her Majesty.

Thank you to everyone who has guessed so far, please feel free to have more attempts.

Have a great weekend,

Alison x

P.S. I’m off to make chicken noodle soup now, but after that I’m going to put some more sale cards (see image) into my shop.

Number 255

Even if you have only been with me a short while, you probably need no introduction to my red shirts. They have featured in most of my work since I started to interfere with the internet.

I have a small piece here, made from nine of the said shirts. Each shirt has been worn and worn-out by one of my colleagues, day-in and day-out.

I have made about eight of these so far, each one featuring a different combination of people. They are for the people to whom the shirts once belonged. This is an extra one, to put in my shop.

You can see who owned the uniforms below.

Alison

Music Together by Geoffrey Winters, published by Longman in 1978. Illustrated by David McKee and Doreen Winters.

Last night I was sorting through stuff from my Upcyclist days (looking for a New Baby card for the lovely Glynis) and I came across these gems.

They are very personal, as the book in question is my own. I used to carry it to school every Tuesday,  between 1979 and 1980. The beautiful illustrations made me smile then, and they make me smile now.

My music lesson did not make me smile, I lived in constant fear of having to sing in public, and I still do. When I say ‘music lessons’, understand that I am not talking about private lessons where you eventually come away being able to play an instrument. I don’t come from the kind of family who do that sort of thing. I mean a ‘music lesson’ in a rough-as-hell comprehensive school in the North- East of England, where the teacher split the class in half and we sang London’s Burning in a ’round’ for an hour.

I love the first one. Dorset Cereal boxes are my favourite for sewing, it really makes me laugh when I see the ‘allergy advice’ just creeping into view near the couple in bed.

I am putting the first four into my shop, the rest are too teeny-weeny, so I will give them as little gifts as and when the mood takes me.

Alison x

246

Kingsway English, Junior Series Book 1 by J.C. Gagg, with drawings by Drake Brookshaw. Published by Evans Brothers Limited, London 1953. This edition published in 1963.

Numbers: 246 – 248 and 302 – 338

One day last week I had a day of uninterrupted bliss, in the house on my own. When I say ‘day’, what I mean is ‘between school drop-off and pick-up’, but it was bliss, nevertheless. You take what you can get.

Anyway, I made these three first birthday postcards.

As usual, they are made from cereal boxes.

The blue card around the numbers, literally came from a bin. I actually took it from the bin (and not the ‘recycle’ one, either) myself. It was left over from something someone had been making at work, not sure what.

The blue fabric with the small floral print, from which I cut the numbers, was a dress belonging to my daughter. She’d be four or five, I guess. I’m smiling as I look at it. She was so cute in it. I can’t remember buying it, but the chances are it came from a charity shop, since most of our clothes do.

Now the book I used. I’m not certain about this, because the pages were not attached to the cover. When I acquire something now, I document it straight away, or that is my aim. However, when the children were younger, I just threw stuff in a pile, perhaps making a note on a scrap of paper. So although I am 99.9% certain that the postcards are made from the above mentioned book, I’m not 100% certain (see P.S. below). I found the cover of  said book with the details attached by paperclip, written buy me in messy haste. The pages certainly look like they once belonged to the cover.

Plus, the illustrations certainly look like they are the work of the great Percy Drake Brookshaw. Very little is known about Drake Brookshaw, but his style is very recognisable, and I know that he did illustrate a lot of academic children’s books. He was born in Southwark, London in 1907 (the year our old house in Hither Green was built, I like thinking about that kind of thing), and died in 1993. If you think you don’t know him, you do. He designed a lot of those iconic posters for London Transport between 1928-1958. He also taught at Goldsmiths’ (my old stomping ground) for quite a while. I found him in the prospectus for 1947/48. Thoroughly enjoyed reading the directions to New Cross by tram or omnibus.

Anyway, the evidence is quite great, so I decided to put them in my shop anyway.

Hope you are warm, and have a great weekend,

Alison x

P.S. I can now confirm that it is the book I thought it was! These illustrations are indeed by Drake Brookshaw, I found some more pages from the book last week (10th December, 2013).

247

248

3

Happy Tuesday morning, pretty cold out there.

I started writing a blog in January of this year, in order to keep a record of the history of the materials I use.

My first ever post was about ‘Birds’ by Brian Wildsmith. I spent the next couple of months making cards from this 44 years old book, and enjoyed every minute of it. In the end (or maybe not), there are now 14 posts on my blog regarding this subject. They are categorized as ‘1-78′, if you would like to read them.

The first nine cards are Christmas birds (you can see them here), not very appropriate at the beginning of the year. I filed them away, thinking I would put them on Folksy this Christmas. I remembered about them as I was walking to work on Sunday, so I have put what is left in my shop. There are more cards from this book to come, but these are the only Christmas ones.

Just a reminder, there is a complimentary card with every order before 15th December 2013.

Have a great week,

Alison x

My daughter has a radio alarm clock which wakes her at 6.50am. She has it set to a radio station that her dad and I look down our noses at. When she came downstairs she had already heard the news.

“First Polly, then Fin, then Grace’s rabbit, and now Nelson Mandela is dead,” were the first words she said to me this morning.

Polly was my sister’s cat. She was 24 actual proper years old. She died exactly a week ago, my sister is devastated.

Fin was my daughter’s fish. He had been on his last legs for a couple of weeks. There were once two fish, Fin and Snowy, but Snowy died not long after adoption. They are pictured above, modelled with that DIY dough you make with flour and loads of salt, and bake for about a week. On Sunday, when I arrived at work I checked my emails. One from my daughter, “fin is dying but his not dead yet”. When I got home from work, he was gone. She cried and cried, and could she please have a pet that she can actually cuddle and play with?

Her friend Grace had the cutest rabbit you have ever seen. He was called Bob, and was a house rabbit. I’m laughing when I say this because I made the mistake of using the term ‘house rabbit’ in the presence of my dad, once. I will not make the same mistake again. He has many things in life which he could get angry about, but he picks this. Apparently, there is NO SUCH THING AS A HOUSE RABBIT. On and on and on. Bob died yesterday whilst Grace was at school. He was only about 6 months old, so don’t know what happened as this story came down the schoolgirl grapevine.

…..and now Nelson Mandela is dead. Such a great man, put into the same category as a fish, a rabbit, and a cat. I don’t think he would mind.

I was a student in London in the eighties, and was involved in anti-apartheid protests. There was another group of students on the other side wearing disgusting badges. I can’t even bring myself to type what they said. And now those students are on television,  showing sympathy. Mr. Manela was a great man, but I am not so great. I cannot forget or forgive.

Rest in peace, Polly, Fin, Bob and Mr. Mandela, you all did great stuff. Some, more so.

Have a great weekend,

Alison x

Kingsway English, Junior Series Book 1 by J.C. Gagg, with drawings by Drake Brookshaw. Published by Evans Brothers Limited, London 1953. This edition published in 1963.

You may recall that the last time I posted about this book I wasn’t totally certain that I was actually sewing with the book in question. Well, earlier this week I found the title page, so now I know that these illustrations were indeed drawn by the great Percy Drake Brookshaw.

Anyway, I’ve made some more postcards using the same fabrics I used here.

The pink floral fabric, which I’ve never mentioned before, was my daughter’s blouse. It was a gift from a friend, and my daughter wore it for her sixth birthday party. She is now eleven.

Pretty cool to think that these pages are exactly fifty years old. John and Jane feature quite heavily, John getting excited when the postman arrives, and Jane going to the shops with a shilling.

Now that my son has taught me how to cut and paste, I should be able to put them into my shop more easily!

Have a great weekend,

Numbers: 313 – 320

I’m on a bit of a roll with these postcards. It’s all the threes today. You can find out more about this book, which is fifty years old, here. And buy the cards here, if you so wish.

Those eagle-eyed amongst you may recognise the green fabric as Del’s shirt, which I used for the mother’s clothes in my Picasso piece.

The dark pink fabric is a pillow case I made for my daughter when she was two-ish. I made Reggie, her teddy, one too.

The pale pink fabric is also used here.

The red, green and purple card, I quite literally removed from the bin at work. By the way, my daughter was scavenging for titbits in people’s recycling bins on the way to school this week. What have I done?

Drake Brookshaw’s illustrations on this batch are particularly beautiful. Love the party where the children are playing ‘Blind Man’s Bluff’ (313). Well that’s what we used to call it, anyway. What on earth does it mean? Apart from tripping over the carpet and knocking yourself senseless, because your eyes are covered with Uncle Derek’s football scarf. On 314 Jane is playing with a doll, whilst John is playing with cars (of course), although it’s nice to see Jane with a fishing net a bit later on. The snowman illustration (318) is a delight, too. Jane playing in the snow wearing her beautifully tailored coat, and John in his shorts. I like 317, as well, where John discovers he is the wrong way round in the mirror.

See you on Friday, when I’ll be having a little giveaway for anyone who has liked my Facebook Page,

Improve Your Golf by Bill Cox. Penguin, 1963, First Edition. Cover Design by Bruce Robertson.

I’m shutting down for a couple of weeks.

You know I have no smartphone and stuff, and sometimes find it an effort (if I’m honest), all this facebooking and twittering and blogging at the computer screen. It takes me away from my making.

From today until Friday 3rd January I will not be interfering with the internet, except for the odd tweet and blog visit.

In honour of this, I am giving away a pack of 15 Upcyclist cards. I haven’t sorted them out yet, but one from the image below will be included. It is made from a book which is 122 years old!

Facebook friends will know that a few days ago I bought the above book in a charity shop (I have now become a tad obsessed with Penguin Handbooks). It is very entertaining. I never knew, for example, that you can smoke whilst playing golf but you can’t move your head, or that there is such a thing as plus-twos.

Anyway, in order to enter, please answer the highlighted question, which I found in the book. As I know nowt about golf, I’m not sure whether the answer is commonly known, or whether the author made it up in 1963 and nobody  has heard of it since.

Please write your answer below as a comment, and the winner will be the first correct one, in the event of lots of correct ones. I will not comment on your answers until the end of the Giveaway.

In the event of no correct ones, I will pick the one which I consider to be the most amusing.

In the event of nobody entering, I will select a name from my Facebook likers.

Lines will close at High Noon on Thursday 2nd January 2014. I will announce the winner here, and on Twitter (not on Facebook), on Friday 3rd January. If nobody comes forward  with contact details, I will pick another winner the following Friday.

To enter, answer the following question:

According to Bill Cox, what are the 5 deadly sins of golf? (they all end in ‘ing’ – no obscene ones, please)

Thank you all for your overwhelming support and kindness, I am always amazed when somebody takes the time to comment. May your days be merry and bright, and may 2014 bring you whatever you need.

Keep on swimming….

Love,

Alison x

Improve Your Golf by Bill Cox. Penguin, 1963, First Edition. Cover Design by Bruce Robertson.

Happy New Year Folks!

And the giveaway winner is……D, who was the first person with the correct answer (slicing, hooking, tipping, fluffing and socketing – all of which sound pretty painful).

Six people commented, six more than I expected, so I have decided  to send you all a card by way of a thank you.

Vicky, you were the only other correct entry.

Cathymarathon, you made me laugh with your ‘farting on the green’.

Richard, your ‘bling’ (I had said all of the answers end with  ‘ing’) answer is still making me laugh as I write. It’s a bit David Shrigley.

Tina and LadySarahinLondon, you did not enter, but as always you took the time to comment.

I will email you all later regarding shipping details, so check your junk.

If you would like to enter a giveaway which has actually been thought through, then look here. There is a massive prize, of which I am just a small part.

So anyway, I’d best get off and sort out my parcels.

I will leave you with some words from David Shrigley, “Santa Claus is not evil, there is no need to defend myself against him”.

Alison x

Update – 4 Hours Later: The prizes are now packaged up. Fourteen cards for D, the winner, and a card each for everyone else who commented. They will be posted first thing tomorrow morning from the large Post Office, just off Trafalgar Square, on my way to work. Everyone has now been sent an email, still waiting for addresses for Vicky and LadySarah.

Earlier this week I had set aside a day in which to have a good clear-out. And by clear-out, I actually mean to throw some stuff away, stuff that normal people would’ve disposed of years ago.

I honed in on a large pile of magazines, given to me by a friend and never opened.  And that was as far as it went. Yes, by the end of the day, nothing had been dumped except the remains of a single, ruthlessly butchered, Vogue. There is something wrong with me…

Rewind to the last Sunday of 2013. I was on my way to work, when I decided to buy a newspaper to read on the train. Every December, I spend weeks reading, and watching on television, reviews of the year. If I looked hard enough, I could find newspaper reviews going back thirty years, obituaries too.  I did some large  pieces to record the events of 1985, 1986 and 1987 (I think), but I sold those at my degree show, and didn’t have the foresight to take the buyers’ details.

So, I’m on the train, and an article (by Gethin Chamberlain, I unsuccessfully tried to add the link) about Katy Perry’s eyelashes leapt out at me. The conditions of the young women in Indonesia, who skillfully make this stuff, is outrageous. I will save that for another post.

Back to Vogue. The next few hours were spent cutting false eyelashes from virtually every face in the magazine.

The next few-ish hours after that were spent cutting out every single letter of the alphabet, and placing them in my twenty-six, carefully arranged, margarine tubs. I am thinking, these letters will come in handy to make some more of those Punkish ‘Love You’ cards (see above, and guess the background anyone?). I am thinking, I could start making those right now.  Oh, and I really want to do a piece commemorating people who died/die in January, why don’t I have a bit of a mess around with the names of the recently deceased?… Hello, it’s time to pick up my daughter…

The new-style Punkish ‘Love You’ cards won’t be finished for a while (you can see my progress below). I need to find some new old postcards, or come up with an alternative method. There are some Jane Eyre hearts  in my shop at a reduced price, though, if you are interested.

Other things of note this week:

1.My blog had its first birthday.

2.We (husband and I) have finished watching Breaking Bad. We watched the lot in about six weeks, and have been totally consumed by it. Me more so, of course. Can’t get it out of my system. We have been greeting each other with ‘Yo Bitch’ for some time, but I fear it may spill over into conversations with innocent bystanders, if I’m not careful.

Have a great weekend, and respect the chemistry,

Alison x

My quest to find some 1970s postcards, so that I can make some more Punkish Love You Cards, has failed.  I am still hopeful.

Meanwhile, back at the Bat-Cave,  I have made two new cards with the cover from Penguin Handbook 94,  subject of my recent giveaway. As usual, each card is a one-off. I just couldn’t resist using that yellow as a background. The book was dropping to bits, not surprising, what with it being fifty years old. Heck, I’m falling to bits. I have become a bit obsessed with Penguin Handbooks, and with Bruce Robertson covers in particular. I am going to start a Pinterest Board.

You will be able to find them in my Folksy shop at some point over the weekend. I am not very happy with the envelopes I have made, my needle was a little blunt, so will list them when Mr. Del Monte (me) has said ‘Yes’.

Work continues on my Breaking Bad cards. *SPOILER ALERT*

So far I have two quotes.

‘Just Basic Chemistry’ which is said twice in the first series. Walt says it to Jesse, and Jesse says it to Badger. I will probably end up with eight of these, all being well.

Another quote I’m using is ‘Wanna Cook?’, said to Jesse by Walt. Unfortunately, question marks are difficult to come by.

The quote I really want to use is, ‘There’s more than just chemistry here’. Walt says this to Gretchen in a flashback. I think it contains too many letters, but intend to try anyway. I have gone completely against the grain, and ordered some 1970s New Mexico postcards on Ebay. Impulse buy. They haven’t arrived yet, but I’m looking forward to seeing how well they sew.

Have a great weekend,

From the end of November until the beginning of January, Walter White and Jesse Pinkman were very welcome guests in our home. They entertained us every evening. They were great company. But now they have gone, they are still here.

I am attempting an exorcism by making some Breaking Bad Valentine’s (or whatever) cards.

I wanted to make some in the style of my Punkish ones, as they seem to ‘fit’. If you have seen them, you will know they are made from vintage British  postcards. I obviously needed the American equivalent, for this new version.

In an excited frenzy, I did the unthinkable. I turned to Ebay. Nothing wrong with that, I hear you say. And indeed, there isn’t. But it goes completely against the grain, for me. It is absolutely not what I do. I use stuff up, I don’t acquire more stuff and ship it half way across the world. So this purchase, of a 1970s Albuquerque postcard book, was doomed from the start. Plus, it was expensive. Not to mention the hours I spent searching, in the first place.

And so, I started cutting out letters and assembling quotes, ‘Wanna Cook?’, ‘Just Basic Chemistry’, ‘Buy the Rv, we start tomorrow’ and so on. All the time, I’m thinking that these letters will be too big for the postcards.

My package arrived yesterday, beautifully wrapped and in a lovely envelope covered in stamps. I will use this envelope. The postcard book is in immaculate condition, still in the cellophane, and certainly 1970s. The thirteen postcards I was expecting turned out to be six, as they are double-sided, and the card is quite thin.

Of course, now that I have it I must use it. Otherwise that carbon footprint will be for nothing.

I was up very late last night cutting out my quotes, only to discover the obvious, they are too big. I stayed up even later cutting out smaller letters. This morning I was woken at five by a car alarm, so here I am. The children are having their breakfast now, at the same table which thirty minutes ago was covered in quotes.

Alison x

If you have been following the making of these cards, you will notice that the above quotes are now mounted onto yellow  instead of red. I spent today cutting and remounting every single letter. Ironically, there was a strange chemical reaction between the glue and the shiny red card, so I had to do them all over again.

I have now finished eight Valentine’s cards. They are not numbered yet, but  you can see scans below. They are unfolded, showing the front and back. I used all seven of the Ebay 1970s Albuquerque postcards. The eighth card (Buy the RV, we start tomorrow) is made from the lovely envelope in which the postcards arrived.

They will not be for sale until next week, as I have not made any envelopes yet.

I will post again on Monday with more details.

Have a great weekend,

Alison x

Numbers 400, 401 and 402

Well, I have now finished twenty-three Breaking Bad cards.

My intention is to post about the making of all of them, before listing on Folksy. I expect it will take four or five posts. I am hoping to have them in my shop on Wednesday or Thursday.

The first eight are made from a 1970s Albuquerque postcard book. It was published by Petley Studios Inc.,  Albuquerque, C1975. I searched Ebay for hours, before finally ordering, and then immediately regretted it. You see, I do not go looking for stuff, stuff finds me. These postcards came all the way from America, an unnecessary addition to my carbon footprint, and were pretty expensive. When they arrived, the card wasn’t as thick as I had hoped. And instead of the thirteen postcards advertised, there were actually only seven,  printed back-to-back. On the plus side, the condition was excellent, it was still in the cellophane wrapper, and it was very 1970s. It was packaged beautifully, with a lovely thick white envelope covered in apple stamps, which I used to make the eighth card.

‘Just Basic Chemistry’  is said twice in the first series. Walt says it to Jesse, and Jesse says it to Badger. 

‘Wanna Cook?’, is said to Jesse by Walt, also in the first series.

All of the letters have been cut from old magazines and leaflets.

I’m going to bed now. This post only took four and a half hours…

I’ll do some more in the morning,

Alison x

Number 407

Continuing with those Breaking Bad cards. Remember the envelope that the 1970s Albuquerque postcard book arrived in? Well this is the card I made from that envelope.

I also used  a bit of the postcard book. That’s an aerial view of Albuquerque (Petley Studios Inc., Albuquerque, C1975) on the right hand side.

The quote ‘ Buy the RV, we start tomorrow’, is said by Walt to Jesse, in Series 1, and made me laugh.

I have made twenty-three Breaking Bad cards, each one completely unique. Once I have recorded all of them here, I will list them in my shop. I am aiming for Wednesday evening.

More later,

Alison x

407 Front and Back.

Numbers 408 – 413

More Breaking Bad cards.

I have made six in this style. All unique.

‘Just Basic Chemistry’ is said twice in the first series. Walt says it to Jesse, and Jesse says it to Badger.

They are mounted onto recycled card, not my usual style of used food packaging. I have made cards for as long as I can remember, but only started selling them when my son was born, thirteen years ago. Although I have always used cereal boxes, and the like, to make cards for my friends and family, in the early days I didn’t think anyone else would buy them. So I bought a thousand (yes!) pieces of ready-cut recycled card. This card now sits under my sink. When the quotes I had mounted turned out to be too big for my usual card,  I decided to try and use the under-sink card. It works, I think.

As you can see, I have sailed a bit close to the wind on 413, so won’t be putting this in my shop. It’s such a bummer when this happens. Hours of work had already gone into this card and then I mess it up at the very end, and there is nothing to be done. Not like sewing with fabric, where (although very annoying) it can be unpicked and sewn again. When you are sewing with paper and card, if you make a mistake it can’t be redone because the needle holes are still there.

I now have thirteen Breaking Bad cards left to record, then I will put them in my shop,

More coming soon,

Alison x

I have made cards for as long as I can remember, but only started selling them when my son was born, thirteen years ago. Sorry about the lateness of this post ( I had said I would do it this morning), our electricity went off at 3am and returned at 4pm. ‘Flooding in the box’, whatever that means.

So this is my last Breaking Bad post. I may make some more cards at some point, but not for a while, and maybe using different quotes. The quote potential is endless.

I have made twenty-ish cards, these are the final six. You can see the others here, here, here, here and here. I am aiming to start listing them in my shop tomorrow.

The letters have been cut from old magazines and leaflets, and then sewn onto (non-greasy) pizza boxes. Everything was destined for the bin, so super eco-friendly, and as usual each one is totally unique.

‘Wanna Cook?’ is a quote from the first series. Walt says it to Jesse. I spent ages looking for those question marks.

Don’t know how much you know about the Brontes, but I sometimes give a talk about the painting, in the gallery where I work. You know, that famous-ish one, their brother painted? Truth is, I don’t talk about the painting much, it’s not very good. I talk about their grandfather and father.

The grandfather lived in Ireland and was a renowned storyteller. This was in days when not many people could read. Folks would come from miles around, just to sit around the fire listening to his stories. They would hold onto his every word, and not want to leave.

This is how I feel about Breaking Bad. We may be living in modern times, but there is not much difference. I would look forward to the storyteller visiting us each evening and telling  one hell of a yarn. I did not want each installment to end. I was consumed by it. I have not felt this way since reading The Life Of Pi. It is not the same, by the way, if you know what happens. You must be innocently led to the slaughter, lamb-style.

My husband, who made a brief appearance on my Facebook Page today (and got more likes and comments than I ever get – although,  someone unliked me – no doubt an Everton fan), tells me I should not compare everything to The Life of Pi (book, not film). Breaking Bad is my benchmark now, although some episodes weren’t as top notch as others.

So here are the final six,

Alison x

Happy Friday.

Just a quick post to give you a brief glimpse of some new cards.

They are all made from vintage postcards, some of which still have writing on the back.

I’m dashing off to make some envelopes. I’ll be using a 1940 map again, so pretty fragile.

I intend to post about each one individually, as they all have a story to tell. If I can get my act together, I may do the first post later today.

The postcards are: Weymouth (1970s), Folkstone (1950s), Walmer (1970s), Whitstable (1970s), Sevenoaks (1950s), Charing Cross Station (1968), Wick (1970s), Bournemouth (1973), and,  Lyme Regis (1984).

They will not be in my shop until I have made the envelopes, and I now have three hours to myself…

Alison x

351

A Salmon Cameracolour Postcard, Printed in England. J. Salmon Limited, Sevenoaks.

Number 351

I love this card. The young boy pushing the boat out and his friend watching on the bank, at the end of the sixties, when they start selling hippy wigs in Woolworth’s. Oh, and Jesus sandals with socks, very 1969.

At one point (9th  September, 1969) in the life of this postcard,  Marjorie sat down in Milford-on-Sea and wrote the following to Mrs E. Parks in Solihull:

Thank you so much for your letter. I hope the lovely monsters arrived home safely. I’m having a very happy and relaxing time, only wish it was longer. The weather has been, and still is, lovely – almost too hot at times. Much love, Marjorie.

Can’t help but wonder what those lovely monsters are doing now.

Forty-five years later, I gave the postcard another life. I cut out some letters from old magazines and mounted the words ‘Love You’ onto an exhibition advert’ from work. I work in a London gallery, and when an exhibition comes to an end any leftover paraphernalia is put into the recycling bin. Unless I get to it first. If you look carefully beneath the letters, you will see a leaflet for an exhibition about Elizabeth 1. Queen Bess moved over a few weeks ago to make way for David Bailey.

The envelope is made from a 1940 Ordnance Survey map of Anglesey. Actually, it’s more of a wallet than an envelope. I wouldn’t recommend putting it in the post, what with it being 74 years old. The card and envelope have a combined age of 139 years! As usual, I have made no attempt to erase the blemishes left by life.

Dovedale Hotel, Bournemouth. Dear G C F, we are spending a holiday here. This is our second week. The weather was lovely last week, not so good this week, but we are enjoying the break. Have been to Salisbury today. Hope you’re both ok. Bertha and George.

People from foreign climes laugh at our weather obsession, they can’t understand it. The thing is our weather is so damn temperamental, that of course it is a constant talking point. It is the main topic of conversation on a postcard, because it can make or break a holiday in the UK. The person you are sending it to needs to know that it wasn’t raining solidly for a fortnight. There are a huge amount of people suffering from seven weeks worth of flooding, as I write. My heart goes out to them.

If there is a child in your life for whom you need to buy a gift, but are at a loss about what to buy, you cannot go wrong with a magazine subscription.

When my son, now thirteen, was about six, a friend bought him a Beano subscription. Probably the best gift he has ever been given.

Similarly, for the past three birthdays my father-in-law has bought my daughter a subscription to Animal Action, the RSPCA magazine for children. She was first introduced to this magazine by my lovely bootsale-ing friend, Sally.

Sally and I were students together. She is like The Scrounger from The Great Escape, if you need something she will find it for you. Sometimes you don’t even realise that you need a thing until she presents you with it. The last time I saw her she produced a cheese grater, remembering that I have been using a broken one for years. Sally is the kindest person ever, when she visits it is like Christmas. Her children are older than mine so we have had years of wonderful cast-offs.

So one day Sally turns up with a treasured pile of Animal Actions, once owned by her two daughters, and before this, her niece. They were an immediate hit, and this was observed by Grandpa. Birthday present problem solved.

When the magazine drops on the mat, excitement fills the air. My daughter always enters the competitions and sends in artwork, once proudly having a picture of a horse published.

A few days ago a parcel arrived. I thought it must be from my mam, she is always sending parcels to the children. She lives three hundred miles away. Later, my daughter opened the package to find out that she had won a prize, a board game called Mask ‘n’ Ask. She was more than happy.

The best thing is this, however, she wrote a letter to thank Georgia (the Animal Action lady) and tell her how much she liked the prize. Totally unprompted. She does waffle on a bit, telling Georgia about Sally’s girls, and her giraffe exhibition (if you follow me on Facebook you will know about this), but it is pretty endearing.

If you have children, you will know that they never cease to amaze you. Sometimes in a good way, and sometimes in a bad way. I regularly feel that I am not a very good parent, but when she showed me this letter I felt that maybe we have done something right.

Have a great weekend,

Alison x

The ‘Giraffe Exhibition’ which has been happening in our house for about six weeks!

The prize.

Mr and Mrs Smiles of Blackberry Farm.

I have been making cards for years, and have had many incarnations. Now and again I have a clear out (ie. I get the shoe boxes from under the bed), and this is one of those times.

During the next couple of weeks I am going to put some of these old cards into the SALE section of my shop, as they contain my old name and contact details.

The  two cards here are made from a copy of Emily The Goat, which I found on a skip in Brixton around 1993. I actually climbed into the skip to get them, oh yes. There were about seven books in the litter, all covered in cement and a tad stinky. The others are probably in my attic now, who knows?

Blackberry Farm is a series of children’s books written by Jane Pilgrim and beautifully illustrated by F. Stocks May. The farm is a fictitious place, on the outskirts of an unnamed British village. It is owned by Mr (check out the cravat) and Mrs Smiles, and their children Joy and Bob. The animals have the ability to speak and understand English. There are twenty-five books in the series, this one being the first. It was published in 1949, but this edition was printed in the 1980s by Hodder and Stoughton.

I’m afraid I didn’t write down many publishing details, I hadn’t yet evolved into the extreme-note-making nerd I am today.

And talking of my nerdiness, I can actually identify the cereal maker by just feeling the box. Let me tell you, these cards are made using Nestle, the most superior of all the card.

I will sign off now, before I fall even further from grace…

Have a great weekend,

Alison x

Joy, Bob and Emily The Goat.

This month I am making a determined attempt to get some of the ‘old stock’ from under my bed, and into the sale section of my shop. These are cards I made years ago, onto which my former contact details have been written. I will put a new card into my shop each day, for the whole month. Each will cost £2.50, less than half the price of my current cards. They are totally unique and come with a sewn upcycled envelope.

I will apologise now, as I intend to cut and paste this first bit tomorrow.

Although it will only scratch the surface, I aim to try and post (however briefly) every day for whole month.

Anyway, first up is the above card made from ‘Madeline in London’ by Ludwig Bemelmans. It depicts a London gent doing a bit of window shopping. As usual, it is made from a cereal box and is super eco-friendly, as everything used was rescued from the bin. The book was first published in 1962, but this edition was published by Hippo in 1989. I have no recollection of acquiring the book, but I’m sure it will have been beyond repair.

I adore Bemelmans, he was something of a maverick. If you are not familiar with the Madeline books, boy they are good. At first glance you are taken in by the beautiful illustrations.

And then you meet Madeline:

‘She was not afraid of mice,

She loved winter, snow, and ice,

To the tiger in the zoo

Madeline just said, “Pooh-Pooh” ‘

Did I mention all of the books rhyme? Except ‘Madeline’, who never quite rhymes. The publishers wanted this changed, but Bemelmans wouldn’t budge. See what I mean? What’s not to like?

Once you know feisty Madeline, you are hooked, she takes no messing. A spunky female role model. A free spirit. She attends a boarding school in Paris. Pepito, the Spanish Ambassador’s son lives next door. In this book, Pepito moves to London and the schoolgirls visit him.

Madeline (who by the way, celebrates her 75th birthday this year) is a character who stays with you, like Pooh, Clarice Bean, Pi and Jesse Pinkman. But I don’t know who I love more, Madeline, or Bemelmans himself.

Bemelmans lived life on his own terms. He was born in 1898 in Austria/Hungry and died in New York City in 1962, at the age of 64. He became an American citizen in 1918. He didn’t start writing until he was 46, and had his first book published when he was 50. Again, what is not to like?

There are many Bemelmans quotes, but this is my favourite, “We are writing for children, but not for idiots.”

See you tomorrow,

Alison x

When I was married, my mam (that’s not a typo, by the way) gave me this tablecloth as a gift. It had been the tablecloth she brought out of the airing cupboard every Christmas. It was only ever used for that one meal. So, I’m guessing it had 16 airings.

Mam can’t remember when and where she bought it. It had a bit of a fifties vibe to it, so maybe it was passed down. She can’t remember any details. What she can remember, however, is me cutting a huge hole from the middle of it when I was about 17 (1984 – my Dad was on strike at the time, I’m using this as an excuse) to make myself a scarf-cum-bandanna to tie around my head. There was no print in the middle of the tablecloth,  just plain red – I was going for a kind of New Romantic look. After 1984 it was never used again, obviously. Mam was furious.

When I opened the gift I couldn’t believe it, because annoyingly Mam never keeps anything. She found it in my cupboard at home and thought it would give me a laugh. There it was, complete with hole and gravy stain (she makes the BEST gravy) on one of the candles.

I have thought about using it a number of times since, but nothing came to mind, and then it became lost on Fabric Mountain. It is a lovely print, candles and hearts. I intend to make  Valentine and Christmas (yes, ridiculous I know) cards. It will be hard to let them go.

I did not intend to add another ‘Madeline’ card today, but something my dad just said made me change my mind. He was telling me that a load of people I know are on their way down to Wembley to watch Sunderland play (football), and it reminded me of another football related story he told me years ago. It was about his first visit to London, again to watch a match at Wembley, when he saw Buckingham Palace for the first time and stood gazing through the gaps between the big black railings. He pointed out to me the exact spot at which he stood. It must’ve been such a shock. This was a boy who never wore shoes. Even within a very poor pit village, they were the poor family. The ‘dirty’ family. When his first visit to London came around, he was seventeen, and had already been working down the pit for two years. At this point he had kitted himself out in some lovely clobber.

He fell over getting out of the bath last week and broke a couple of ribs.

Anyway, so this is why I picked this card to put into my shop today.

‘Talkabout Starting School’ by Margaret West and Ethel Wingfield. Illustrated by Harry Wingfield. Ladybird, 1977.

Harry Wingfield died on this day in 2002 at the age of ninety-one.

He taught me to read. Not in person, but by making the reading of those relentlessly boring Peter and Jane ‘stories’ more bearable. I loved looking at his illustrations. The family in the pictures were far removed from my own family, but I appreciated those watercolours nevertheless.

He was a freelance illustrator for Ladybird Books for three decades, retiring in the 1980s. He portrayed a wholesome world, without divorce and disobedient children. Jane helped Mummy in the kitchen and Peter helped Daddy with the car.  Although, in the 1970s Jane ditched her pretty frock for jeans. We did that sort of thing in the Seventies.

I loved his work then, and I love it now. He also did some abstract stuff, for the Ladybird Junior Science series.

The text for this particular book was partly written by his wife, Ethel, who played the piano to accompany silent films.

I was ten years old in 1977, when this book was published. Although the children in my Victorian school yard were much messier than the children here, I did have an anorak just like than navy-blue one at the front. Red-lining and all. We didn’t have things to climb on, either, just an empty yard.

‘Where’s Julius?’ by John Burningham. Red Fox, 1995.

John Burningham writes and illustrates the most captivating books. He has over sixty under his belt, the first of which was published more than fifty years ago. Not a dud amongst them. He works hard to get his books right, he knows they have to be good.

“It is terribly important what children have to read.” He says, ” I fear for this generation, I know there are tremendous benefits we get from technology, but just staring at a screen worries me somewhat. It has to be cool to read a book”.

‘Where’s Julius?’ is all about Julius’s dad trying to deliver a meal to the adventurous Julius. I remember reading this particular copy to one of my classes. They kept asking for it over and over again. I can still see their little faces laughing as I read. So, when it was time for ‘Where’s Julius?’ to go to that giant library in the sky, I just had to bring it home with me. It had given many classes before mine lots of pleasure, and was absolutely knackered.

John Burningham is the UK nominee for the 2014 Hans Christian Andersen Award, the highest recognition available to creators of children’s books. The results will be announced later this month, 24th to be precise. The award is given every two years, and he has reached the final in the past. The jury summed up his work perfectly, “John Burningham from the UK, uses delicate irony mixed with innocence and high seriousness that, with his use of line and colour, creates an intimacy with the reader.”

This particular card shows Julius digging himself into a hole!

‘Tales From Postman Pat’ by John Cuncliffe, illustrated by Celia Berridge. W.H. Smith, 1986.

I am annoyed.

Years of teaching in a primary school has given me a decent knowledge of children’s literature, but I know nothing about Celia Berridge, the illustrator of the above card.

So, I searched the internet. Nothing, or very little information about her life. Plenty of books she has written and illustrated, but not much about her as a person. How many times have I trawled the internet trying to find information about a woman illustrator and found zilch? Many times. The emphasis is on the ‘woman’ illustrator, if you didn’t pick that up. Don’t get me started.

Eventually I found some details on a 1976 dust jacket. At the time she was living in Greenwich, London, with her husband and two children. She had been a teacher and taught in primary schools in Deptford and Bermondsey.

John Cuncliffe, however, could be my specialist subject on Mastermind. I have been a big fan of his for many years. My job here, though, is to give the illustrator credit. So please accept my apologies, Celia.

As to the history of this particular book…no idea where I acquired it.

About ten years ago I walked into a charity shop to hear the manager complaining about the ‘tat’ that some people donate. She was saying, to the assistant, that nobody in their right mind would want to buy the stuff in the bag she was holding. That may indeed have been true. I bought the stuff.

One of the items was this badly torn annual, the same vintage as myself. Turns out, after spending five hours internetting last night, this particular annual is quite rare. If it had been in good condition, it would’ve been worth some money. I have no idea where the book is now of course, somewhere in the attic I expect. In a safe place. I made a few cards from it in 2012, three of which I recently found under the bed.

All three cards are made from a story written by Leslie Charteris entitled ‘The Silver Chute’, starring Simon Templar as ‘The Saint’. Suave Templar is enjoying the high life of Las Vegas, when he stumbles across a dead body in a casino. The man has been poisoned! The Saint fights off various attempts on his life, charms a mystery lady known as The Countess, and uncovers a large heist of stolen goods. All in a day’s work…

This particular card shows a street scene, with flashy car and cacti!

Unfortunately, I cannot give the illustrator credit. There is no name recorded in the book (a collector checked his copy for me), and hours of internet searching gave no reward.

3a Things We Like by W.Murray. Illustrated by Martin Aitchison. Published sometime in the Seventies by Ladybird Books.

Martin Aitchison was born in 1919. He went to Birmingham School of Art, followed by The Slade.

Deafness prevented him from active service during the war. Instead he worked as an illustrator at Vickers, where he supported new developments including the ‘bouncing bomb’ for Barnes Wallace.

After the war he worked for various advertising agencies and newspapers, and in 1953 began a ten year stint at ‘Eagle’ and ‘Swift’ comics.

After The Eagle’s demise in 1963, Martin worked for Ladybird for over twenty years, illustrating nearly one hundred books.

This card shows a thoroughly British teatime scene, which I think will make a nice Mother’s Day card. I have also included (below) an image of the Sixties’ version of the same book. This time the illustration is by Harry Wingfield, I think, I cannot be totally certain as I no longer have the card (and didn’t keep notes in those days). If it’s not Harry Wingfield (and I’m pretty certain it is), it’ll be John Berry.

Since posting this five hours ago, I have found the card below. I wasn’t even looking for it, I thought I’d sold/sent it. Turns out the illustrator is John Berry.

3a Things We Like by W. Murray. Illustrated by John Berry. Published by Ladybird in the Sixties.

John Berry was a Hammersmith lad, born in 1920. He died four years ago.

He won a Royal Academy Scholarship, but the war prevented him from taking it. He was a war artist and a lot of his work is now housed in The Imperial War Museum.

After the war he painted portraits. He provided a service at Harrods (where else?) whereby you could drop off a photograph and he would reproduce it in oil.

He has illustrated many children’s books, not just Ladybird, but it is Peter and Jane which brought him to my attention. Here we see them angelically admiring the daisies. A Mothers’ Day card maybe? Below is the Seventies’ version of the same scene, this time by Martin Aitchison.

Martine a la Ferme by Gilbert Delahaye. Illustrated by Marcel Marlier. Published by Casterman, 1954.

Marcel Marlier was born in 1930 and died in 2011.

He started children’s book illustration when he won a competition organised by La Procure a Namur, the Belgian publisher. He stayed with the publishing house for over twenty-five years.

Following this, he worked for Casterman, where he illustrated the ‘Martine’ series which spans over fifty issues.

This was the first of the series, published in 1954. It was posted to me, anonymously, in a very bad state. It is a first edition.

I am working on a collage, using an old Ordnance Survey map as a base.

The map is seventy-four years old, and is falling to bits. Initially, my only aim was to sew it back together. I patched a little hole with a picture, liked how it looked, so continued patching.

I am enjoying myself. It is such a manageable size for bus and train sewing.

Anyway, I want to record what I’ve used so far, so I don’t forget. Mostly, they are bits of old books, too small to use for anything else, but too precious to throw away.

1. The Rabbits’ Wedding by Garth Williams. Picture Lions, 1973. I love little daisies. Someone has decided that they are weeds. Some flowers are more equal than others.

2. Lindy and Bill, and a rabbit/hare from High On A Hill by Mabel O’Donnell and Rona Munro. Illustrations by Florence and Margaret Hoopes, and Christopher Sanders. Published by James Nisbet and Co., this edition 1966.

3. Some bloke in the crowd, from that wonderful Penguin golfing book, the inspiration for my nuts giveaway.

4. A Joyce Badrocke illustration. I harped on about Joyce endlessly, on my Facebook Page a few weeks back. Reminds me of my mam, back in the day. Everyone’s mam wore a scarf like that, or they did where I lived, anyway.

5. A scrap from that Albuquerque postcard book I bought on Ebay during my Breaking Bad obsession, still ongoing, by the way. Incidentally, the red square above the daisy is also a little nod to Breaking Bad.

To do the rest I need to hunt through sketchbooks for notes. A job for the weekend.

Have a good one,

Alison x

This is not what I intended to be writing about today, but you’ve got to roll with the punches.

I was either going to write about the fact that my uniforms piece is ready to collect from the framer’s, or about a couple of postcards I recently made from a 1965 record sleeve.

However, all that changed when I heard about the death of Sue Townsend.

My sister and I have always loved her.

My cousin, David, who is a year older than me, was always giving me books to read when we were at school. He introduced me to many great characters, one of which was Adrian Mole. We went to a rough-as-you-like comprehensive, in one of the most deprived areas of the country. There was a lot of glue- sniffing in my school. There were also a lot of extremely bright, overlooked kids. Our David was one of them. He is the son of a factory worker (my dad’s younger brother, who escaped the pit), and now works in a betting shop in our home town.

Over the years, meeting students, teachers, professors, professional people, I have often had the same thought. They are not nearly so bright as the kids I went to school with.

I came to London at nineteen to go to art college. It was the Eighties. It was Goldmiths’. I didn’t know about snobbery. Hard to believe, but I didn’t.

On the first day, we sat in a circle and discussed our favourite books. Mine, Adrian Mole. There were sniggers. I was crushed, and didn’t really talk again for the rest of the course. I became almost reclusive. It seemed everyone else knew what to say, and how to say it.

I knew I was different as I watched my fellow students arrive in their parents’ cars, loaded up with useful stuff, like pans and towels. I arrived on my own, on the National Express coach from Durham  to Victoria, with one bag on my back. I got the 36  from Victoria, when I actually said the words “You can have my seat missus”. Also,  I shouted a ‘thank you’ to the driver as I got off the bus. At home you would have never got off a bus without shouting ‘Thank you Driver”. To this day, I have always thanked the driver, sometimes a wave, too.

This morning I sent a quick email to my sister and  our David,  just saying ‘Sue Townsend has died’, below is the reply from our David. I’ve no idea why the font changes.

Thanks for the laughs, Sue.

Alison x

I’ve just heard on Radio 5………..so sad………….I can’t believe poor Adrian is destined to be eternally unhappy and not fulfilled in his life!! The last couple of books had me both near to tears and laughing on the same page more often than not. I knew she was struggling with her health recently, with diabetes and blindness.
The side-story of his son with Sharon Bott, who he tried to guide along the right path despite being little more than dragged up, but because of poor education ended up in the Army in Iraq (or Afghanistan, I forget which!), and what happens with that is truly heart-wrenching……….it makes you not want to turn the page sometimes………yet finding yourself hurrying to do so!!!
 A true literary great of our lifetime………RIP Sue.
 Hope you are all well,
David
xxx

It can get pretty draughty if you are positioned at one of the entrances to the gallery, where I work. Despite this, in six years, I have never once complained, until today.

Recently, the seat at the shop door has been moved to its ‘summer position’, four steps lower than the ‘winter position’,  the latter protecting the sitter from the winter winds.

We have had some beautiful sunny days here in London lately, but the mornings have been particularly chilly.

I was positioned in the new ‘summer position’, when the gallery opened this morning. It was like being in a wind tunnel. I radio-ed my boss to ask if it was okay to move the seat back to the ‘winter position’.

I thought that I was absolutely frozen to the bone. Luckily, my boss came to the shop door and confirmed that, in fact, I wasn’t cold after all, so no need to move the seat.

When I went for lunch, the person who took over from me thought she was cold, too. Fortunately, she wasn’t.
